Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER: Education Initiative TECH MeD: Transdisciplinary Education for Critical Hacks of Medical Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
TECH MeD (Transdisciplinary Education for Critical Hacks of Medical Devices) seeks to engage a broad audience about the cybersecurity implications of remotely accessible, implantable medical devices. The project will educate undergraduate and graduate-level students from various disciplines, healthcare professionals, patients, and the general public about the ethical, legal, social, and technical implications of these remotely accessible devices. Growing the population of security-aware end-users of implantable medical technology, the initiative will address one of the most critical links in the cybersecurity chain. TECH MeD will equip them with the knowledge and skills necessary for the appropriate handling of this technology.

TECH MeD will include four educational tools: 1) An online open-access course that features expert interviews on important topics to create an informed public, aware of the host of issues associated with implantable medical devices; 2) An undergraduate and graduate course that will create a pipeline of cognizant and prepared professionals to address the present and future challenges of this proliferating technology; 3) A Continuing Medical Education (CME) course that will provide medical professionals with an overview of the issues they are likely to encounter on the front lines of medicine; and 4) An open-access website document repository for the general public with useful information for educators, students, and patients. The website will ensure the continued success and widespread education of the TECH MeD initiative by offering easily understandable information for patients, their families, and all other laypersons seeking information on implantable medical device security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the Transdisciplinary Education for Critical Hacks of Medical Devices (TECH MeD) project, we sought to develop a variety of educational programs and materials for different levels of learners about contemporary issues related to cybersecurity and medical devices. In particular, our programs focus on the technical, medical, legal, and ethical issues associated with the potential for medical devices - especially remotely accessible, implantable devices - to be breached and altered by hackers.  Through the collection of written materials and interviews with scholars and industry experts, we developed educational programming intended for undergraduate and graduate students, physicians and other health professionals, and the general public.  In this programming, we explore issues such as why patients have medical devices implanted, how medical devices are regulated in the United States, how the hacking of medical devices occurs (technically speaking), and steps taken (and those that could be taken) by regulatory agencies, medical device manufacturers, hospital physicians, and patients to understand the concern and potentially mitigate or protect against it.

This project resulted in 5 major educational “products”: a massive open online course (MOOC) developed through Coursera, an online continuing medical education program, an undergraduate course syllabus, a graduate course syllabus, and a public repository of all course materials. 

The Coursera MOOC, called TECH MeD: Transdisciplinary Education for Critical Hacks of Medical Devices, is designed for members of the public across the globe.  The course, which is divided into 5 modules and includes videos as well as reading materials, offers learners the opportunity to both study course content and actively engage with their peers in online discussions about the material presented.  To enroll in the Coursera course, go to coursera.org and search for "tech med".  You will then see the course listing. 

Our continuing medical education course for health care professionals enables learners to earn 0.5 hours of continuing education credit through the University of North Texas Health Science Center to learn more about the topic. To enroll in this course, go to http://ce.unthsc.edu and type the following phrase into the search box: "cyber security".  

On our online, public repository for the material we developed and collected for our educational programming, learners will find not only videos and reading materials but also undergraduate and graduate course syllabi for modules on cybersecurity and medical devices.  The syllabi detail how to integrate the video clips and reading materials at the appropriate level for undergraduate and graduate student learners.  Furthermore, the syllabi are designed so an instructor can simply integrate the modules/materials into existing courses or develop new courses based solely on the material.  Texas Christian University hosts this online repository. To visit the repository go to techmed.tcu.edu.

 


Last Modified: 08/09/2018
Modified by: Michael Bachmann
